summary: Which MCU films give women the most screentime?
title: Which MCU films give women the most screentime?
description:
This is Why Captain Marvel matters A LOT in the MCU! 

Wonder Woman did it first, but Marvel has a major issue when it comes to Female Screentime, and now that Brie Larson is in the suit & doesn’t conform to certain male fanboys ideology they are going after her and the film with full force!

tags: a great movie go watch it
summary: captain marvel was so great! can y'all believe that women weren't sexualised?!? they were strong and actually empowering! also...
body:
captain marvel was so great! can y'all believe that women weren’t sexualised?!? they were strong and actually empowering! also nice action, plot and jokes.

and like,, carol dressed in grunge style.. beautiful. carol showing monica it’s okay to be strong and smart.. iconic. maria being ready to help her best friend even if it includes going to space.. true.

all in all, we stan.

summary: Captain Marvel review: 9/10 only cried 2 times. Second time was the obvious very motivational ‘fall down seven times, stand up...
body:
Captain Marvel review: 9/10 only cried 2 times. Second time was the obvious very motivational ‘fall down seven times, stand up eight’ scene in every marvel movie. The first time around it was actually me getting furious at this society for not making movies like this when was younger and needed it most. 
Very happy for young girls that can identify.

reblog.comment:

Very happy for young girls that can identify.

blog.name: worklabournewsresearch
blog.title: work&labour news&research
blog.description:
The latest information in 
Industrial Relations and Human Resources, 
from the CIRHR Library at the University of Toronto.
Stories from the tumblr are collected weekly in PWR: work&labour news&research, which is published from September to June.

summary: International Women’s Day: Too Much Marketing Strategy?
title: International Women’s Day: Too Much Marketing Strategy?
body:
“The release date of Marvel’s first solo female superhero film was deliberately timed to coincide with International Women’s Day. But is this a celebration of women or a bit of a cynical ploy? International Women’s Day has become something of a media, cultural, and commercial event in recent years.  This year, for example, alongside Captain Marvel, soap operas Emmerdale and Neighbours have announced special episodes with all-female cast and crew.”

“It’s a great marketing strategy, but the line between celebration and cynical cash-in is a fine one. Several commentators have criticised the commodification of IWD and the emphasis on projects such as these media launches over raising awareness of more serious issues affecting women globally.”

“Having a female-fronted and directed Marvel superhero film is to be celebrated, of course – though its release on IWD may be too cynically opportunistic for some. Hopefully, Captain Marvel will entertain and inspire audiences – men as well as women. But the fact that it is still an exception, rather than the norm, shows us that the film world still has a long way to go before women achieve anything approaching equality.”

The Conversation, March 7, 2019: “Captain Marvel: why female superheroes are not just for International Women’s Day,” by Ruth Deller  

Wonderland Magazine, March 7, 2019:  “International Women’s Day Film: Annie Lennox’s teamed up with The Circle and Apple Music on a short film for International Women’s Day”. 

International Women’s Day in Toronto

“International Women’s Day is a day to thank the women in your life for everything they do. It’s also a day to celebrate all our historic achievements and, most importantly, to remind everyone there’s still a lot more work to be done.”

“Even with misogynists trying to drag us down, women have many achievements to celebrate.  There was closing that sex doll brothel that let men live out their darkest fantasies, and it took three years to shut down a misogynistic newspaper spewing hatred against women and Jewish people. Of course, Doug Ford’s government immediately rolled back the progressive new sex-ed curriculum – stripping out references to consent, gender identity and same-sex relationships.”

“Nonetheless, women rallied together in freezing temperatures for the Toronto Women’s March in January, proving nothing can stand in the way of equal rights. So grab your girl gang and head to these inclusive events for women and allies. Maybe bring Brad and Chad – they could learn a thing or two.”

NOW, March 4, 2019: The best International Women’s Day 2019 events in Toronto: Celebrate women’s rights and gender equality at these panels, parties, concerts and more by Marianna Lozowska

Google News search on International Women’s Day

ILO Report for International Women’s Day

“The report highlights key gender gaps and obstacles to decent work for women. It explores the structural barriers, including unpaid care work, that shape the nature and extent of women’s engagement in paid employment, and examines how laws, policies and practices in certain countries have addressed them. The report also outlines the measures that can and should be taken to seize the opportunities presented by the changing world of work.”

ILO, March 7, 2019: A quantum leap for gender equality: For a better future of work for all: This report is the culmination of the extensive and often ground-breaking work undertaken in the ILO’s Women at Work Centenary Initiative. It is closely aligned with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development ( 74 pages, PDF)

Business Insider, February 2019: “RANKED: The 19 best countries to live in if you’re a woman,” by Alison Millington
